message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest primary amenorrhea, and the family history and physical examination suggest delayed puberty. FSH and estrogen levels will help determine if there is a gonadal or hypothalamic-pituitary issue. Pelvic exam and prolactin level are not likely to reveal the cause of the patient’s symptoms, and GnRH level is not necessary at this point.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest primary amenorrhea, which can be caused by a variety of factors such as genetic abnormalities, hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction, or structural abnormalities like an imperforate hymen. To determine the cause, FSH and estrogen levels would be most useful as they can indicate if the patient has ovarian failure or if there is a problem with the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Pelvic exam would not be useful in this case as the patient has not started menstruating and her physical exam does not suggest any structural abnormalities. Prolactin level and GnRH level may be useful in certain cases, but in this case, FSH and estrogen levels are more appropriate initial tests.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest primary amenorrhea, which can be caused by several conditions such as Müllerian agenesis, Turner syndrome or hypothalamic dysfunction. FSH and estrogen levels can differentiate between these conditions and guide further management. While a pelvic exam may be useful in some cases, it is not necessary in this patient as she has not yet undergone menarche. Prolactin level and GnRH level may be useful in other cases, but are not as important in this particular scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including delayed onset of menstruation, fatigue, constipation, and coldness, suggest hypothyroidism or hypogonadism. A pelvic exam may be needed if a structural abnormality is suspected, but FSH and estrogen levels are more relevant in assessing ovarian function and diagnosing hypogonadism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation suggests primary amenorrhea with symptoms of hypothyroidism. Among the options, only FSH and estrogen levels can distinguish between primary and secondary amenorrhea and can help diagnose the underlying cause of primary amenorrhea. A pelvic exam, prolactin level, and GnRH level may be helpful in further evaluation, but FSH and estrogen levels are the most important in this initial workup.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has primary amenorrhea and symptoms suggestive of hypothyroidism. FSH and estrogen levels can help diagnose if the patient has primary ovarian failure or another cause for her amenorrhea. Pelvic exam is not necessary at this time since she has not yet started menstruating. Prolactin level and GnRH level may also be helpful in certain cases, but FSH and estrogen levels should be done first.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest primary amenorrhea, and the most useful test in determining her diagnosis would be the measurement of FSH and estrogen levels. Pelvic exam can help rule out structural abnormalities but it is less useful in determining the cause of amenorrhea. Prolactin level can help rule out hyperprolactinemia, but it is not the most useful test in this case. GnRH level is not necessary for primary amenorrhea as the most common cause is hypoestrogenism, which can be detected by FSH and estrogen levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest primary amenorrhea and possible pituitary and thyroid problems. FSH and estrogen levels can determine if there is a problem with the development of primary sexual characteristics or if there is a hormonal problem. Pelvic exam can also be useful but only after the hormone levels are determined. Prolactin level and GnRH level are not the most useful in determining the diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest primary amenorrhea with signs of hypogonadism. The most useful test would be to measure FSH and estrogen levels. A pelvis exam would be useful to evaluate secondary sexual characteristics, but would not determine the cause of the patient’s amenorrhea. Prolactin level would be useful in a patient with galactorrhea or visual field deficits. GnRH level would not be useful in this clinical scenario as it is not a diagnostic test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a diagnosis of primary amenorrhea. The most useful test for determining the diagnosis is FSH and estrogen levels. Prolactin level is more useful in evaluating galactorrhea, while GnRH level is not necessary unless there is clinical suspicion for a hypothalamic disorder. Pelvic exam may provide information about anatomical abnormalities, but does not provide information about hormonal imbalances.
